source_file: A_80_6 (SECT. 3)_ADD.3_CLUSTER II_FASCICLE ADVANCE UNEDITED COPY FOR ACABQ.json

content.text: A.	Proposed programme plan for 2026 and programme performance in 2024

children.text: Overall orientation
Mandates and background

The Panel of Experts on Haiti is responsible for monitoring the implementation of the travel ban, asset freeze and territorial arms embargo, as well as for providing information relevant to the potential designation of individuals and entities. The mandate is referenced in Security Council resolution 2653 (2022), renewed in subsequent resolutions, including most recently, 2752 (2024).  The sanctions regime is aimed at, but not limited to, supporting the efforts of the Haitian authorities to deliver stability and security in Haiti, to counter gang violence and criminal activities and prevent human rights abuses.

On 1 October 2024, following a request by the Council in its resolution 2700 (2023), the Secretary-General provided the Council with an assessment of the progress achieved on the key benchmarks modified in the same resolution  (S/2024/711). By its resolution 2752 (2024), the Council requested the Secretary-General to provide an update by 1 October 2025 on progress made against the key benchmarks.
Programme of work
Objective

The objective, to which this mission contributes, is to ensure the full implementation of the sanctions regime concerning Haiti, which includes a travel ban, an asset freeze and a territorial arms embargo.
Strategy and external factors for 2026

To contribute to the objective, the Panel of Experts will provide updated information to the Security Council and the Security Council Committee established pursuant to resolution 2653 (2022) concerning Haiti.
The above-mentioned work is expected to result in an enhanced capacity of the Security Council and the Committee to take follow-up action on alleged violations of the sanctions regime.

With regard to cooperation with other entities, in line with paragraph 22 of resolution 2653 (2022), the Panel of Experts will cooperate with, among others, Member States, in particular neighbouring countries, and regional and subregional organizations, such as the Caribbean Community, including the Eminent Persons Group appointed by the Caribbean Community, the Organization of American States and the multinational security support mission in Haiti.

With regard to inter-agency coordination and liaison, the Panel of Experts will cooperate with, among others, the United Nations Integrated Office in Haiti (BINUH), the Multinational Security Support Mission in Haiti, the Focal Point for Delisting to support the review of petitioners’ requests to be removed from sanctions list, UNODC and other sanctions monitoring teams, groups and panels, as appropriate. In the context of safety, security and logistics, the Panel will cooperate with the Department of Safety and Security, BINUH and UNDP.
With regard to the external factors, the overall plan for 2026 is based on the following planning assumptions:
(a)	Member States comply with the resolutions of the Security Council and cooperate with the Panel of Experts;
(b)	The security situation allows the Panel of Experts to conduct missions, as needed.
Programme performance in 2024
Committee members receive information on gang dynamics, arms trafficking and illicit exploitation of natural resources

In 2024, the Panel of Experts submitted interim (S/2024/253) and final (S/2024/704) reports to the Security Council with substantive information on the security situation in Haiti, including gang dynamics, their activities and leadership, and on individuals that met the designation criteria, including those supporting the gangs. The Panel also provided information on arms trafficking into Haiti and recommended, inter alia, strengthening the territorial arms embargo. The Panel also recommended updating the sanctions designation criteria to target individuals or armed groups engaged in activities that destabilize the situation in Haiti through the illicit exploitation or trade of natural resources.
Progress towards the objective is presented in the performance measure below (see table 51).
Table 51 – Performance measure

table_content.text: Establishment of a group of 4 experts, which will assist Committee in carrying out its mandate, gather, examine and analyse relevant information, provide an interim and a final report to the Council, and assist the Committee in refining and updating information on listed individuals and entities

Security Council and Committee received the mandated reports and information on individuals and/or entities meeting the designation criteria; Council adjusted sanctions measures based on the recommendation of the Panel of Experts and the Committee designated additional individuals

Security Council and Committee received information on individuals and/or entities meeting the designation criteria; Council adjusted sanctions measures based on the recommendation of the Panel of Experts and the Committee designated additional individuals

children.text: Planned result for 2026
Full implementation of the sanctions regime concerning Haiti – Programme performance in 2024 and target for 2026

The Panel  contributed to the full implementation of the sanctions regime, which met the planned target. Following the Panel’s recommendations, the Council strengthened the territorial arms embargo and included designation criteria in relation to the illicit exploitation or trade in natural resources. The Panel also provided the Committee with information on individuals who met the designation criteria, following which the Committee added two individuals to its sanctions list.
Lessons learned and planned change

The lesson for the Panel was that, owing to the volatile security environment in Haiti that prevented the Panel from spending substantial time on the ground, the Panel had to adjust the approach in conducting its investigations. In applying the lesson, the Panel will revise its investigative methodology, while ensuring it meets the highest investigative standards. The Panel will continue working with BINUH and the Department of Safety and Security to implement all necessary security risk mitigation measures.
Expected progress towards the objective and the target for 2026 are presented in the performance measure below (see table 52).
Table 52 – Performance measure

table_content.text: Establishment of a group of four experts, which will assist Committee in carrying out its mandate, gather, examine and analyse relevant information, provide an interim and a final report to the Security Council, and assist the Committee in refining and updating information on listed individuals and entities
Security Council and Committee receive the mandated reports and information on individuals and/or entities meeting the designation criteria
Security Council and Committee received information on individuals and/or entities threatening the peace, security or stability of Haiti and designated additional individuals

Security Council and Committee continue to receive information on individuals and/or entities threatening the peace, security or stability of Haiti and consider designating additional individuals and entities

Security Council and Committee continue to receive information on individuals and/or entities threatening the peace, security or stability of Haiti and consider designating additional individuals and entities

Table 53 – Deliverables for the period 2024–2026, by category and subcategory

B.	Generation and transfer of knowledge

7.	Missions to gather information relating to compliance with the sanctions regime

content.text: B.	Proposed post and non-post resource requirements for 2026

children.text: Resource requirements (regular budget) – Table 54 – Financial resources
(Thousands of United States dollars)
Table 55 – Human resources
a 	Other level unless otherwise stated.

The proposed resource requirements for the Panel of Experts for 2026 amount to $1,794,300 (net of staff assessment) and would provide for the salaries and common staff costs ($622,400) for the continuation of three posts (1 P-5, 1 P-3 and 1 General Service (Other level)), and operational costs ($1,171,900) comprising expert fees ($526,800) and travel ($225,200) of the four experts, official travel of staff ($171,700) and travel of Close Protection Officers ($178,700) from various United Nations entities to support the experts while travelling in Haiti, and other operational and logistical support requirements, including the rental of premises, rental of vehicles, communications and information technology services and other supplies, services and equipment ($248,200).

For 2026, no change is proposed to the number and level of posts for the mission. A vacancy rate of zero per cent has been applied to the staff costs for both international and national staff on the basis of the average vacancy rate in 2024.

The increase in the requirements for 2026 compared with the appropriation for 2025 is attributable primarily to higher requirements for civilian personnel, owing to the application of a lower vacancy rate compared with the rate of 33.3 per cent applied in 2025 and increased requirements for expert fees. The increase is offset in part by the lower requirements for telecommunications and network services and the application of latest OICT standard rates.
